Suppose I have two hypotheses: h₁ : x = 0 ∨ x = 1 and h₂ : x ≠ 0. I can then get h₁ : x = 1 from simp [h₂] at h₁.

But now, let's assume instead that x = 0 ∨ x = 1 is a theorem: theorem myTheorem (x : ℝ) : x = 0 ∨ x = 1 := sorry (please disregard the obvious nonsense math here...). I can't directly use the above since that leaves simp [h₂] at myTheorem, which does not make sense.

Is there some canonical way to deal with this situation (not just when x : ℝ)?
Like you can have h₁ : x = 1 := (myTheorem x).resolve_left h₂
I was trying to avoid doing have -- it seemed like something that should be possible in a one-liner (I could be wrong of course)
Ah, I was a little quick. This works: apply (myTheorem x).resolve_left h₂
Björn Wehlin has marked this topic as resolved.
